results:
Based on the search results, I found comprehensive information about the original German text of Goethe's "Die Leiden des jungen Werthers" from the 1774 and 1787 editions:

## Key Findings:

### Original 1774 Edition
The novel was first published in 1774 by Weygand in Leipzig, consisting of 224 pages. The first edition of September 1774 was published anonymously, with three further editions being published in the same year. Goethe, aged 24 at the time, finished Werther in five and a half weeks of intensive writing in January to March 1774.

### 1787 Revised Edition
The novel appeared as a revised edition in 1787. In 1787, Goethe made minor revisions to the work. The 1787 edition was published by Göschen in Leipzig as part of "Goethe's Schriften. Erster Band" (Goethe's Writings, First Volume), consisting of 310 pages. Goethe substantially reworked the book for the 1787 edition and acknowledged the great personal and emotional influence that The Sorrows of Young Werther could exert on forlorn young lovers.

### Differences Between Editions
The search results indicate that the revised 1787 text includes additions such as "Was in dieser Zeit in Lottes Seele vorging..." (What went on in Lotte's soul during this time...) after the letter of December 20th.

### Available Resources
1. The Deutsches Textarchiv (German Text Archive) has a digital version of Goethe's Werther from 1774
2. A parallel edition comparing both the 1774 and 1787 versions is available from Reclam Universal-Bibliothek
3. The Herzogin Anna Amalia Bibliothek has a digitized version of the 1787 edition

### Literary Impact
The Sorrows of Young Werther turned Goethe, previously an unknown author, into a literary celebrity almost overnight. The novel immediately became one of the most famous best-sellers and long-sellers in literary history, and also contains the first mention of a Christmas tree in German-speaking literature.

The parallel editions available today allow readers to compare the original 1774 Sturm und Drang version with the more refined 1787 Classical period revision, showing Goethe's evolving literary style and maturity.
